content: The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" provides for a final settlement of the claims of the Colorado Ute Indian Tribes by agreeing to reduced water supply facilities. The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" defines key terms such as Agreement, Animas-la plata project, and Dolores project. The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" defines key terms such as Project, Dolores Project, and Tribe/Tribes. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE COLORADO UTE INDIAN WATER RIGHTS SETTLEMENT ACT OF 1988. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to include the construction of a reservoir with a storage capacity of 260,000 acres-feet as part of the Animas-La Plata Project. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to include the construction of a reservoir with a storage capacity of 260,000 acres-feet as part of the Animas-La Plata Project, along with a pumping plant and reservoir inlet conduit for municipal and industrial water allocations to the Southern Ute Tribe. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to include municipal and industrial water allocations to the Southern Ute Tribe, Ute Mountain Ute Indian Tribe, and Navajo Nation, with specific annual depletion limits for each tribe. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to allocate specific annual water depletion limits to the Southern Ute Tribe, Ute Mountain Ute Indian Tribe, Navajo Nation, San Juan Water Commission, and Animas-La Plata Conservancy. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to allocate specific annual water depletion limits to various entities, including the Navajo Nation, San Juan Water Commission, and Animas-La Plata Conservancy District. The Navajo Nation is allocated an average annual depletion limit of 10,400 acre-feet of water, the San Juan Water Commission is allocated 2,340 acre-feet, and the Animas-La Plata Conservancy District is allocated 2,600 acre-feet. The Navajo Nation, San Juan Water Commission, and Animas-La Plata Conservancy District have specific annual water depletion limits allocated to them. The Animas-La Plata Project's nontribal water capital repayment obligations will be satisfied by the San Juan Water Commission upon full payment. The nontribal municipal and industrial water capital repayment obligations for the Animas-La Plata Project shall be satisfied by the San Juan Water Commission, Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District, and the State of Colorado, totaling $29,000,000. The Animas-La Plata Project requires a total capital repayment of $29,000,000, with contributions from the San Juan Water Commission, Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District, and the State of Colorado. The State of Colorado's portion is $16,000,000 as part of a cost-sharing obligation from a previous agreement. The State of Colorado entered into the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement and Animas-La Plata Cost Sharing agreement on June 30, 1986. Nonreimbursable costs for certain components of the Animas-La Plata Project include recreation, environmental compliance, cultural resource protection, and fish and wildlife mitigation. Tribal water allocations for municipal and industrial use from the project are specified. The State of Colorado's agreement on the Animas-La Plata Project includes nonreimbursable costs for recreation, environmental compliance, cultural resource protection, and fish and wildlife mitigation. Tribal water allocations for municipal and industrial use are specified, with the Secretary covering operation, maintenance, and replacement costs until the water is used by the Tribe. The Secretary will pay for operation, maintenance, and replacement costs for tribal water allocations for municipal and industrial use until the water is used by the Tribe. The Tribe is not required to reimburse the Secretary for these costs. The Tribe is not required to reimburse the Secretary for the payment of any costs related to the allocation of water. Repayment of the Tribe's pro rata share of construction costs for the Dolores Project will commence when the water allocation is first used by the Tribe. In paragraph (5), if water allocation is first used by a Tribe or pursuant to a water use contract with the Tribe, repayment of construction costs for the Dolores Project will begin, and the Tribe will start bearing annual operation and maintenance costs. This is in accordance with the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988. The Tribe will start bearing annual operation and maintenance costs for the Dolores Project as per the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988. The Secretary will provide necessary action for water supplies at the request of specific water conservancy districts. The Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to provide water allocations to specific water conservancy districts in Colorado and New Mexico, not exceeding 5,230 acre-feet annually, as per the Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998. After the Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998, water allocations are provided to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado (5,230 acre-feet annually) and the La Plata Conservancy District of New Mexico (780 acre-feet annually). Additional water depletions may be permitted beyond these allocations. The Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 allocate water to the Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District of Colorado (5,230 acre-feet annually) and the La Plata Conservancy District of New Mexico (780 acre-feet annually). Additional water depletions may be permitted under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The Secretary will allocate water depletions among beneficiaries of the Animas-La Plata Project in accordance with an agreement. Upon request, the Secretary will transfer water rights in a manner consistent with the State Engineer of New Mexico. The Secretary will transfer water rights to New Mexico beneficiaries of the Animas-La Plata Project as requested by the State Engineer of New Mexico, in accordance with applicable State law. The Department of the Interior will transfer water rights to New Mexico beneficiaries of the Animas-La Plata Project in compliance with State law, specifically New Mexico Engineer permit number 2883, dated May 1, 1956. This transfer is to fulfill the project's New Mexico purposes. Additionally, certain reports related to the project will be treated as specified. The Department of the Interior will transfer water rights to New Mexico beneficiaries of the Animas-La Plata Project to fulfill the project's New Mexico purposes. Certain reports related to the project will be considered adequate to satisfy requirements under the Endangered Species Act and the National Environmental Policy Act. The Final Biological Opinion of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service for the Animas-La Plata Project is considered sufficient to meet requirements under the Endangered Species Act, National Environmental Policy Act, and Federal Water Pollution Control Act. This includes amendments from the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act Amendments of 1998. The Final Biological Opinion for the Animas-La Plata Project meets requirements under the Endangered Species Act, National Environmental Policy Act, and Federal Water Pollution Control Act. It includes amendments from the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act Amendments of 1998, construction of facilities, and an aggregate depletion of 57,100 acre-feet of water approved in the biological opinion. The construction of facilities and depletion of 57,100 acre-feet of water are described and approved in the final biological opinion. Nothing in this subsection affects the construction of other facilities or the use of water not approved by the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. Final Settlement: The provision of water to the Tribes as per this section will settle tribal claims to water rights on the Animas and La Plata Rivers. Nothing in this section may affect the construction of facilities or water use not approved by the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The provision of water to the Tribes in accordance with this section will constitute final settlement of tribal claims to water rights on the Animas and La Plata Rivers. Nothing in this section will affect the Tribes' rights to water on other streams and rivers, participation in the Animas-La Plata Project, receiving water amounts dedicated to tribal use, or acquiring water rights under the Agreement. The Tribes' water rights on streams and rivers described in the Agreement, excluding the Animas and La Plata Rivers, are protected. The Attorney General will take necessary actions to amend final agreements in Water Division Number 7 of Colorado. The Attorney General of the United States will file necessary instruments with the District Court, Water Division Number 7 in Colorado to amend the final consent decree for water rights under Colorado law. SEC. 4. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION; TREATMENT OF CERTAIN FUNDS. The amendments made by this Act to section 6 of the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement of 1988 do not affect the applicability of other provisions of the Act or the Secretary of the Interior's obligation to deliver water from the Dolores Project and complete construction of facilities on the Ute Mountain Ute Indian Reservation. The Act requires the delivery of water from the Dolores Project and completion of facilities on the Ute Mountain Ute Indian Reservation as specified in various Department of the Interior Appropriations Acts from 1991 to 1994. The Act mandates water delivery from the Dolores Project and facility completion on the Ute Mountain Ute Indian Reservation as specified in Department of the Interior Appropriations Acts from 1991 to 1994, including the treatment of the uncommitted portion of the cost-sharing obligation of the State of Colorado. The uncommitted portion of the cost-sharing obligation of the State of Colorado, as specified in the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988, remains available after the date of payment. The uncommitted portion of the cost-sharing obligation of the State of Colorado, as specified in the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988, can be used to fund components of the Animas-La Plata Project not covered in the Act.
